title: How to Buy Organic Compost

steps.headline: Buy small amounts of compost from a local nursery or garden center.
steps.description: If you’re just shopping for your home garden, a local nursery or garden center is a good option. They’ll sell bags of organic compost that you can pick up and take home with you. Call ahead to make sure your local nursery or garden center carries compost in-store.

steps.headline: Get large amounts of compost from a landscape or compost supplier.
steps.description: If you’re shopping for organic compost to use for farming, buying from a local supplier is your best bet. Landscape or compost suppliers will deliver large amounts of organic compost right to your door. To find a local landscape or compost supplier, search online for “Landscape supplier near me” or “Compost supplier near me.”

steps.headline: Buy compost from an organic farmer if you want to know exactly what's in it.
steps.description: Some organic farmers make their own compost and sell it to local growers. When you buy from a local farmer, they'll be able to tell you exactly what they used to make the compost you're getting. To find local organic farmers, go online and search "Organic farmers near me." Then, reach out and ask them if they sell organic compost.

steps.headline: Order bags of compost online if you can’t find what you need in-store.
steps.description: There are lots of different kinds of organic compost, and you might not be able to find exactly what you're looking for in a store. If that's the case, look for an organic compost vendor online and order bags to be delivered to your home.

steps.headline: Look for compost that’s been certified as organic.
steps.description: There’s no official governing body that says which composts are organic and which ones aren’t. However, there are smaller groups that give their seal of approval to composts that meet certain criteria. Try to use compost that’s been certified by one of these groups. The Organic Materials Review Institute, the U.S. Composting Council, and the Organic Farmers and Growers Association all certify certain composts as organic.

steps.headline: Avoid compost that has “biosolids” listed as an ingredient.
steps.description: Biosolids are human sewage and waste. Human sewage isn’t supposed to be used in organic agriculture, so you’ll want to find compost that’s biosolids-free. If you’re not sure whether a compost has biosolids in it, look for the manufacturer’s number and give them a call to ask.

steps.headline: Buy compost that doesn’t have inert ingredients.
steps.description: When compost has “inert ingredients” listed on the bag, it’s hard to know what those ingredients are. To make sure you’re buying the most natural and organic compost as possible, stick to compost that has the ingredients specifically laid out on the label.

steps.headline: Buy compost that’s fully decomposed.
steps.description:
Compost that hasn’t decomposed all the way isn’t ready to be used. If possible, examine the compost before you buy it. It should be dark brown and crumbly. Signs that a compost hasn’t decomposed all the way include:
Visible leaves, seeds, and stems in the compost. Large pieces of bark in the compost. Eggshells in the compost.

steps.headline: Choose compost that doesn’t have any trash in it.
steps.description: Sometimes, pieces of trash get mixed up in the composting process. Since some trash is not biodegradable and you likely don't want trash in your yard, you want to make sure your compost doesn’t have any in it. Sift through the compost with your hands and if you discover any trash, look for different compost. Wear gloves when you’re sifting through compost so you don’t cut yourself on any glass, plastic, or metal.

steps.headline: Avoid buying compost that has an unpleasant odor.
steps.description: Compost that’s been properly made and is fully decomposed will have a pleasant, earthy smell. If a compost has a bad, pungent smell, don’t buy it.

text:
Finding Organic Compost Buy small amounts of compost from a local nursery or garden center. If you’re just shopping for your home garden, a local nursery or garden center is a good option. They’ll sell bags of organic compost that you can pick up and take home with you. Call ahead to make sure your local nursery or garden center carries compost in-store. Get large amounts of compost from a landscape or compost supplier. If you’re shopping for organic compost to use for farming, buying from a local supplier is your best bet. Landscape or compost suppliers will deliver large amounts of organic compost right to your door. To find a local landscape or compost supplier, search online for “Landscape supplier near me” or “Compost supplier near me.” Buy compost from an organic farmer if you want to know exactly what's in it. Some organic farmers make their own compost and sell it to local growers. When you buy from a local farmer, they'll be able to tell you exactly what they used to make the compost you're getting. To find local organic farmers, go online and search "Organic farmers near me." Then, reach out and ask them if they sell organic compost. Order bags of compost online if you can’t find what you need in-store. There are lots of different kinds of organic compost, and you might not be able to find exactly what you're looking for in a store. If that's the case, look for an organic compost vendor online and order bags to be delivered to your home. Verifying It’s Organic Look for compost that’s been certified as organic. There’s no official governing body that says which composts are organic and which ones aren’t. However, there are smaller groups that give their seal of approval to composts that meet certain criteria. Try to use compost that’s been certified by one of these groups. The Organic Materials Review Institute, the U.S. Composting Council, and the Organic Farmers and Growers Association all certify certain composts as organic. Avoid compost that has “biosolids” listed as an ingredient. Biosolids are human sewage and waste. Human sewage isn’t supposed to be used in organic agriculture, so you’ll want to find compost that’s biosolids-free. If you’re not sure whether a compost has biosolids in it, look for the manufacturer’s number and give them a call to ask. Buy compost that doesn’t have inert ingredients. When compost has “inert ingredients” listed on the bag, it’s hard to know what those ingredients are. To make sure you’re buying the most natural and organic compost as possible, stick to compost that has the ingredients specifically laid out on the label. Choosing Quality Compost Buy compost that’s fully decomposed. Compost that hasn’t decomposed all the way isn’t ready to be used. If possible, examine the compost before you buy it. It should be dark brown and crumbly. Signs that a compost hasn’t decomposed all the way include:
Visible leaves, seeds, and stems in the compost. Large pieces of bark in the compost. Eggshells in the compost. Choose compost that doesn’t have any trash in it. Sometimes, pieces of trash get mixed up in the composting process. Since some trash is not biodegradable and you likely don't want trash in your yard, you want to make sure your compost doesn’t have any in it. Sift through the compost with your hands and if you discover any trash, look for different compost. Wear gloves when you’re sifting through compost so you don’t cut yourself on any glass, plastic, or metal. Avoid buying compost that has an unpleasant odor. Compost that’s been properly made and is fully decomposed will have a pleasant, earthy smell. If a compost has a bad, pungent smell, don’t buy it.
